General course objectives:
General course objectives
To provide tools for the students to analyze and develop modern systems with digital transmission. Emphasis is put on the description of signals and noise as stochastic processes and in conversion of continuous analog signals to digital form. Models are provided for different transmission channels and the signal processing in some basic transmission systems is analyzed. It is the aim of the course to give both an theoretical analysis of the systems and a demonstration of implementations of the signal processing to facilitate simulation of performance.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Explain the fundamental problems of transmission of information
Use MATLAB for modeling of the signal processing in digital communication
Calculate correlation functions and spectra for deterministic and stochastic signals
Create and analyze Markov models for sources and simple line codes
Calculate spectra for PAM signals and pulse shapes to avoid ISI
Analyze and optimize quantization strategies
Optimize linear estimation
Design optimal receivers for PAM signals and calculate corresponding error probabilities
Optimize linear equalization techniques
Analyze digital quadrature modulation and calculate error probabilities for such
Content: Introduction to basic problems of digital communication. Deterministic signals. Application of stochastic processes in the description of signals and noise. Sampling and quantization of continuous stochastic signals. Examples of user signals, eg. sound and images. Linear estimation and prediction. Baseband transmission of digital signals: optimal receivers, signal design, and simple line codes. Modelling of physical transmission channels: radio channels and optical channels as AWGN. Modulation techniques: amplitude modulation, quadrature modulation, and digital phase modulation.
